comments.commentBody:
I agree. I think we should be thankful that the President isn't falling all over himself to fawn over one of his financial backers. For someone like Rmoney to bring his largest donor along on a trip and lick his boots, and with shallow and reckless abandon profess fealty to that donor's expectations on a matter as weighty as war with Iran, should make the American public want to retch.

Sure, a thank you note would be nice, but I hardly believe that President Obama does not do one better, a 'thank you' in person where possible. If he is introverted (the type who characteristically feel drained by interpersonal relationships) and is able to pretend well enough that he is an extrovert to accomplish what he has been able to thus far, more power to him. It is an impressive feat, speaking as someone who is introverted and struggles to summon the will to be at all sociable.

I get the impression that Ms. Dowd did not get a thank you note somewhere along the way, because it seems to be a recurring theme that she writes about, almost like a jilted lover. - sean

" He is a politician" Reverend Jeremiah Wright, Jr. on then candidate Senator Barack Obama.

POTUS Obama is a politician which means that he will compromise enough to keep getting elected. He is no saint nor savior. The lesser of two evils is still evil. From Washington to Jefferson to Lincoln to FDR to today we are electing flawed human beings.

As voters we too must compromise and vote for the candidate who imperfectly best matches our own views. Obama by that measure was better than McCain. And he is better than Romney.

But he gets no pass when he fails or betrays the things that he has promised or compromised too much. Or become too hypocritical.

Politics is largely about power - getting it, distributing it, rewarding it, etc - which Obama understands intellectually but not emotionally. I think he will win the next election, but this will always be a weak point for him.

Obama has the right idea of what a President should be, but he has the wrong idea about what every politician is in our system.

That condemns the system more than it does him. We need more of what he is, and far, far less of the grasping, pandering politicians we get with our system.

It is fundamentally about the role of money in politics. This is one more thing that highlights what is wrong in our system.

On the one hand I sympathize with those who simply want to earn a living... but I agree with you, she's being exploited by the League and doesn't even realize it.  Eventually the League and its officials will come to an agreement and these 'replacement' refs will never, EVER be accepted by the regular officials, making it highly unlikely that they will ever again work in the NFL.  Lose-lose proposition for all but the League, who will attempt to carry on like nothing happened.
Numerous "scabs" who played in the NFL replacement games in '87 later played in the NFL.

Unfortunately she's still a scab and the history of professional sports shows that whenever somebody tries to take the job of the officials on either strike or lock out, they are never accepted if they are hired by the respective leagues later on.  They are ostracized among their crews.  I am aghast that anybody would scab and try to hurt the incumbent officials.

I was in LA in 1984. I was a regular blood donor, and they were giving away "stars in motion" pins at the blood donation center. It hadn't occurred to me to do any pin trading, but a couple of other donors didn't want their pins, so I had three. And by coincidence, three preschool daughters. I was finishing my dissertation, and used pin trading as a diversion from the writing. I managed to barter those three pins into quite a collection for my daughters. It was also a good lesson in supply and demand. For example, a much coveted Swiss team pin suddenly became just another pin when members of the Swiss team suddenly flooded the market. We still have those pins.
It's just come out that Australia did the same thing. Surely you wouldn't accuse Australia of being a culture that opresses women?

Everyone seems to assume that Japanese culture is going to change quickly, and that women will gain equal status with men immediately. The only time in Japanese history that such a rapid change occurred was under MacArthur, and that was accomplished only by preserving the institutions of the Imperial family and that after a nuclear halocaust.

When one examines the slow pace of the change in gender roles and relationships in our own non-homogeneous society, where over 120 years after the start of agitation for women's sufferance major inequalities still persist, one should not expect rapid change in Japan.

I'm not a fan of baseball themes, but this was snarky enough with STEROIDS that it was more interesting.

Had some Naticks - tried to spell Xenon with a Z, so no MHP.

Thanks to Laszlo for pointing out the full scope of this theme.

adam

YOu have got to be kidding. New York is one of the most expensive cities in the country. Certainly not the place to provide housing for people for free. The country is 3K miles wide. People who don't make enough can commute. When I lived in San Fran during the internet bubble I made $250K per year, yet commuted to save money. WHY do people with relatively modest incomes such as police, teachers, etc... think they should live like rich people e.g. in the inner cities? EVEN more insane is people trying to support themselves on minimum wage. Flyover country is the best place for that.
Excellent point Jason. Come Brunella. Why don't  you buy the bulding and open it the public.

As a NYC public school teacher my students taught me how easy it is to incorrectly believe what politicians or others say "because I saw it on TV". See letters I wrote below published in the NYTimes:

Re '' 'This Week' Is Adding Online Fact Checks'' (Arts pages, April 13):

The article notes that some reporters expect viewers to fact-check the program on their own online. If it isn't the job of the news media to confront people, including politicians, with false or misleading statements intended to hide the truth, that's news to me.

Charles Merrill
New York, April 13, 2010

To the Editor:
Re ''Chairman Exerts Pressure on PBS, Alleging Biases'' (front page, May 2):
The job of the press is to scrutinize government, not praise it. The administration gives its story in the best possible light using taxpayer money. That must be countered by a vigorously critical free press.
When have administrations, either Democratic or Republican, presented evenhanded pictures of what they do? The question isn't whether ''Now'' (formerly ''Now With Bill Moyers'') is critical of the Bush administration but whether it behaved differently during the Clinton administration.
If anything, our press has failed to be critical enough.

Charles Merrill
New York, May 2, 2005

To Whom It May Concern,

While I do not fit into any of the aforementioned preferred categories, I would very much like to contribute to the discussion referenced in this post. I believe I can add quite a bit to the conversation for the following reasons:

1. I am a libertarian-leaning conservative who holds neither party in particularly high regard. I also aim to be intellectually honest, and focus on the facts.

2. I believe the national debt and related issues are the nation's most important issues (tied with abortion), and with the debt and economy being major focuses of both conventions I can add to that discussion. I am co-authoring a book on the impact of the debt on young Americans, and in the book I blame both parties and aim at solutions -- solutions neither party is really looking at.

3. Bipartisanship is necessary in today's Washington, but not in the way people think -- I think most Members are "bipartisan" to get re-elected, mostly. What I would really like to see is the Tea Party and Occupiers work together where they agree (eliminate Big Business and Big Government collusion, for example), and thus truly philosophically-honest people would be influencing major aspects of the public debate.

4. Lastly, I have twice-criticized Mrs. Collins' writings (once on the HHS Mandate and once on her opinion on the Tea Party), and I think we would have an engaging and educational discussion.

Thank you for considering me for the dialogue.

Best Regards,

Dustin

Put simply: Indiana is in some ways the northernmost southern state. Culturally it tends to look more like its southern neighbors than its eastern ones. And unlike Ohio with its three large cities, Indiana's population is mostly either rural, or people who wish they were still rural. Whereas Ohio's core has been urban industrial for generations.

A particular cultural point for this election: Many Indiana residents have a strong "keep the government out of our business" attitude. I think a relatively high percentage are swayed by Tea Party arguments as a result. Also let's not forget how deep the racism runs here, this was the KKK's home not that many years ago. These folks are riled up to see Obama gone.

On the flipside, Obama only won Indiana in 2008 due to a large surge of voters from poor urban areas - populations that historically have low turnout. Even without the Tea Party activitsts, all it would take would be for the Indy and Chicago urban areas to vote at their normal levels to take this state out of contention. Indiana is simply more conservative than Ohio in general.
It's also called conservation and maintenance. Do you know what having hundreds or thousands of people visit does to those cost. They can visit via the internet.

How cool. I remember that hearing that long ago there were apartments or liing quarters at the top of the building for Woolworth family - there must be some gorgeous Art Deco work in these floors and it would be great to see pictures of them.

I do admit to twinge of envy of those who will be able to afford these!

Your comments fall on deaf ears to the powers that be, same pols who think it perfectly OK for NYU to trample over the West Village, same pols who look out for themselves, their friends, and donors, those in the middle and lower classes are left to make do on their own.

Where is the affordable housing that was promised to NY'ers????

Are you listening Bloomberg? Are you listening Quinn?

You're absolutely right Tony! America needs to stop producing goods meant for the consumption of the top 1%.

The only good kind of job creation is the one that is not related to the creation of products for the bourgeois class to consume?

We're in big trouble then!

To Matt from Hong Kong: Re-read my comments. It is not about how rich people should spend their money. It is about providing affordable housing for the rest of NYers--those who will never be able to see NYC as their own personal playground, but the place where they actually work, raise kids, and live. I could care less how a multi-billionaire decides to spend his money. He can buy 50 mansions in NYC for all I care. It becomes a problem, though, when all the building that's going on in the city is directed at these 1 percenters and no resources are being spent at anyone else. Do you really think that if we built homes for the middle class, they would sit empty in NYC? Are you saying building affordable housing will not mean construction jobs, service jobs and tax revenue for the city? That only building playthings for the rich is the only way to create an economic base for a city like NYC? It would be nice to believe in such a delusion, but that's not going to happen.

Yay, more over the top residences for the obnoxiously and conspicuously rich. And just a few blocks from Zucotti Park where Occupy Wall Street protestors got beat up by cops and had their rights trampled on. Meanwhile, those of us who live by the sweat of our brows and not trust funds, eliminating other peoples's livelihoods, or trading on other people's money, get to live in tiny closets. Bloomberg wants to build more 200 square foot studios, and these guys want to build mansions. What about some decent spaces for us who can't afford a $50 million 2 square mile, 20 bedroom palace, but shouldn't have to live in spaces so small they crush our souls?

My name is William Tatum and I am a journalism student at LBCC in Oregon. I an underemployed and currently work two part time jobs and go to school full time. I am a father to a 15 year old daughter and husband to a lovely wife.

I would be worth having on because I won't yell or interrupt and will bring thoughtful questions to the discussion. I voted for Obama in 2008, even spread the Obama gospel to my friends as it were. After the last 4 years however I find myself leaning towards Gary Johnson or voting none of the above(which I know is not a category i just right it in). The Tea party scares me, Occupy is too nascent and diffuse, and personally i see little difference(other than rhetorically) between Republicans and Democrats.

I am mostly interested in finance, targeted kill lists, indefinite detention and the geopolitics of drone and cyber-warfare.

I will not race or class bait, I won't trumpet the Ron Paul end the fed lines, and I will do my level best to eschew dogmatic or ideological talking points.
Such a change from Tri-X and dektol.

Hi, my name is Jake Miller and I'm from Missoula, Montana and I would like to participate in the discussion. I'm from an upper-middle class family and about to enter my first year of law school at Gonzaga law school in Spokane, WA and I'm very worried about the opportunities that will be available once I complete my studies. In addition, I worked at the Wisconsin State Capitol for the past two years in a non-partisan office and feel I have a unique perspective on the partisanship that has so strongly divided our country. Wisconsin has been one of the most bitterly divided states in the country and my work with the Senate engendered an more balanced outlook for me. I believe these two elements of my background fit into your "worried about dropping out of a class" group and "people interested in the future of bipartisanship."

If you would like more information about my demographics, I'm a 25-year old gay white man. I've traveled abroad several times and lived in Alaska, Montana, Hawaii and Wisconsin. Despite my B.A., I was only able to secure a job under 30,000 for the last two years. I voted for Obama in 2008 and plan to vote for him again in 2012, but I consider myself a moderate because of problems my family has had with local government.

3 major issues that I am especially interested in:

Civil rights in all its ramification--gay rights, women's rights, rights of immigrants, and rights of people of color.

Income inequality and fair taxation

both parties are more interested in banks and wall street rather than those who are underwater with mortgages.

I've been in awe of Doug's pictures from the Olympics. I guess I'd gotten used to seeing his byline on so many of the White House/Obama pics that I'd forgotten he does the Olympics too. What an amazingly gifted PJ he is!

Thanks so much, Jim, for letting us get the inside scoop on how Doug does it all. Now I am more in awe than ever!!! So where is the Gold Medal for photogs? Guess we'll have to wait for the World Press Photo Awards.

Patricia Lay-Dorsey

I don't fit any of your categories, but I might still have a contribution to make (in addition to correcting your egregious typo -- "are particular relevant"). I've made (very small) donations to Obama since 2007, and he still has my support. Voting for Romney is completely out of the question for me, as it is for most people my age or younger (I'm 35). I've never voted for a Republican, and I don't foresee that ever changing. Here's what I don't get about Obama or his re-election campaign/strategy: why is he so unwilling to take traditionally liberal stands on policies? Yes, there is value in taking middle-of-the-road positions to appeal to independent or undecided voters -- but Obama is overcorrecting and moving to the right of center on certain issues, which puzzles me. Why is he so afraid of taking a stand against the NRA and in favor of gun control, for instance? What does he gain by going soft on this? Certainly not the votes of any NRA members, who will no doubt vote for Romney. And what does Obama gain by bashing teachers and unions (via Arne Duncan)? While Republicans might smile upon the Obama Administration's anti-union rhetoric and policies, I can't imagine they'd be sufficiently swayed to vote for Obama merely because of his willingness to take a stand against the AFT and NEA. Isn't Obama jeopardizing some of his support from the left -- not because liberals will end up voting for Romney but because they'll be apathetic and perhaps not vote at all?

Can someone explain why they believe Wambach was being a poor sport by counting? It's common in any sport to try to work the officials to your advantage. Its foolish not to do that - because the other team does it so you would be at a disadvantage if you did not. Think about catchers in baseball shifting the glove into the strike zone, basketball players intentionally falling down to emphasize contact was made (or not made) by the opponent, NFL players pointing out to the refs that there are 12 men on the field or any assortment of violations. What Wambach did was play the game well on all levels - and that includes trying to get the refs to make calls in your favor. Why is it any different than the Canadian coach trying to get fouls called against the US players?

Its silly to say that this victory is tarnished - it was a great game and a fantastic victory by the US team. Canada played well but couldn't shut down the US attack in the second half.
There was no aby  wambach shouting repeatedly in the ref's ear- counting  1, 2, 3..... Canada played the game, the US played the insecure ref.

We keep seeing photos of Jordyn Wieber as though we regretted Gabby Douglas was the champ and barrier buster. Wieber has shown herself not just a loser but a sore loser at that. Let's see Gabby and the team. They are the winners!

Mitt Romney's flag-waving display is simply mind boggling after the embarrassment he brought America with his idiotic, insensitive, impertinent, impolitic remarks in London.
How could it have been an 'upset' when the U.S. never led the game at all until the very end?

I agree with that jheller , the American coverage over-emphasizes U.S. participants to the detriment of having complete coverage of an event.

On one swimming race they never even showed the winner once but concentrated on the third place American.

Congrstulations, Aly! You made us so proud with your amazing talent, grace and sportmanship!!! It is amazing how well our girls conducted themselves throughout this competition. It was a pure joy to watch all of them.
